text:
Well, this is the 26th
annual Christmas lecture. And for 20 years, we call it
the Christmas tree lecture.

The idea was that-- well, trees is one of the most
important things to computer

scientists, and
every year I learned, at least, two new cool
things about trees.

And so I could just talk-- every December I could talk
about the coolest thing I

learned about trees that year. And that went on for
more than 20 years. Now, I still learn cool
things about trees every year,

but they're getting
harder and harder to explain to a
general audience.

So starting about
five or six years ago, we just changed it to
the Christmas lecture.

But this year, it's,
again, a Christmas tree lecture because I got--

last year, when I was putting
the final touches on this book,

Volume 4b of The Art of
Computer Programming. Here you see that. [APPLAUSE]

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. I learned something
that I said, oh yeah,

this is going to
be a great lecture and so I'm going to
have fun tonight. I mean, from a
lectures point of view,

it's always best when
you have something that you love to talk about. So now, speaking of
Christmas, by the way,

this book makes an
excellent present. And so, if somebody doesn't
know what to give you as a gift,

why not try suggesting this one. And another thing, I have a
tradition of giving away books

at this lecture every year. So if you look in
front on the floor, there's quite a few books.

Actually, there's three
times as many books this year because we've had two
more years to accumulate.

What happens is that my books
keep coming out in new editions

and every printing is
a little bit different, and I have to check to see
whether they followed it up again.

And also, I get-- books are translated, and I only
need one copy of a translation,

but they send me two and so on. So I have extra spare copies of
books, and they're sitting here.

But I have two rules
about these books. The first rule is
only one per person,

and the second rule
is you have to wait until the end of the lecture
in order to touch them.

So I want somebody to
stay for the whole thing. Now, I'm going to sit
down now, and most of it

is going to be about
these three topics

that I announced,
Twintrees, Baxter permutation, and Floorplans.

And so we start with
number one is Twintrees.
We can't see the top, though. You can't see the top.
Whoops, I can't either. [LAUGHTER]

All right. Now, this idea goes
to the two guys named
Dulurg and Guibert in 1996.

And I have to say
that it's one word. In 1996, they
actually-- they called

it Twin Trees with
the space between it. But then it turned out
that two other guys came up

with a completely different
concept in 1993 that was called Twintrees.

And so these guys wrote
another paper in 1998

and called it twin binary trees. Well, I think that-- I like to make it just one word,
so I'm calling it Twintrees.

And the topic is in Volume
4b in two main exercises.

There's one on page 27
about Baxter permutations, and there's this
one on page 172.

And if I zoom in here on this,
you see that it actually talks

about where do
we-- can you see-- wait a minute, here we go. I got floor plans, but
I also have Twintrees.

OK. But here you see, I still
spell it with two words there,

and the third printing
is going to change that. [LAUGHTER]
What are they?

Well, you might guess
that they're trees.

It's a pair of binary trees. A binary tree is a tree in
which every node has either

no children or-- it has potentially two children,
a left child and a right child,

and both of them have nodes
1 through n when you look

at the tree in symmetric order. And I'll tell you what
symmetric order is in a minute.

And the easiest thing is
for me to just give you an example of our twin
tree, because a twin tree is

a pair of binary trees. And so well, it's
Christmas time. So I'm going to draw
the first one in green.
And so I have a node here. Number 4.

And then here's 2
and here's 2, 3, 6.

This is going to be a binary
tree with 8 nodes in it.
And symmetric order.
So this is in symmetric order.

Symmetric order, you take the
left subtree first, and do it

in symmetric order,
then you take the root, then you do the right
subtree in symmetric order. So it's just reading
it from left to right.
There's 2 of them. So the other one is this. 5, 8, 7, 6.

I got to do something over here. Let's go all the
way to 1, 3, 2, 4.

So this is an example of a
twin tree data structure. And the important
concept is that node k

has a right child, let's say,
in exactly one of the two trees.

And the same thing
for left child and exactly one of the trees.

So this is when k is between
1 and n, but not equal to n.

And this is when k is between
1 and n, but not equal to 1, because 1 never
has a left child.

1 is the first thing
in symmetric order. So it can't have a left child.

So let me just show the left
and right children here.

So let's see. I zoom out a little bit. So if I look at 1,
2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8,

and I write down there the
left and right children,

this is going to be left, and
this is going to be right. And the root of the tree is 4.

And the children
of 4 are 2 and 6. OK. The children of 2 are 1 and
3, children of 6 are 5 and 7,
and children of 7 is 8. 7 has a right child.

Now, if I go to the red
tree, its root is 5.

It's got the left
1 and right is 8. 8 has left is 7,
7 has left is 6.
1 has right of 3, 2, 4. OK. So here you see that this is--

inside a computer, I can share
the red and the green stuff as long as I have a way to tell
which is red and which is green.

They don't interfere
with each other. Exactly k equals 4.

4 is going to have a right
child in one of the trees,

but not in 2. So not going to be any clashes. So now, you might
think that this is
a really unusual construction. I mean, here we have--

maybe you have to search until
you find such a magical thing

that has this great property. But in fact, there are more than
10,000 twin trees of order 8.

And in order to verify that,
let's just generate a random one

right now. So I'm going to need the help
of the people in the front row.
So I have a random permutation.
And actually, OK.

So I'm going to ask you,
there's going to be a 2 in here. It's going to be either on
the right or the left of 1.
What should I do? [INAUDIBLE]

To the right. I just wonder if you were
conservative or liberal. [LAUGHTER]

Now, the 3 has to go in here
somewhere, be at the left
or in the middle or the right. What should I do?
You want-- what? Could you repeat, please? I'm sorry. Just say middle, left or right.

Middle. Middle. I shouldn't have said anything
about conservative and stuff

like that.  Number 4, there's
four places to put it.
What do you think?

Now, this is looking
random enough. I'm going to ask for
the next one because.
Between 1 and 3. Between 1 and 3. Now we got three more to go.
We're ready to go. Ready to go. All right, and--
To the left of 1. You're ready. To the left of 1? So we have extreme-- extremists here.
Now, I'm going to ask--
Let's put it in between 2 and 4. What? Between 2 and 4. Between 2 and 4. That's it.

So anyway-- now
let's look-- now I'm going to show you one of my
favorite algorithms of all time

for more than 50 years is the
algorithm called binary tree insertion.

And you take a
permutation and you--

and you write down
the first element, and you put that in the root. Then you look at the next one.

And if it's less than the
root, you go to the left, so 1 goes here.

The next one is 5. Well, 5 is also less than
7, but it's bigger than 1.

So 3 is less than 7. It's going to go in this
left subtree somewhere. It's bigger than 1, less than 5.
So 3 comes in here. 2 equal-- 2, well, 1-- it's going like this.

8, here we go, and 4. So 8 is less than
7 or less than 5.

So here is 4. And 6 is going to stick in here. So in my-- well, let me do the
red ones, though, because--

so anyway, you can
get any binary tree from some permutation. But now let's take
the same permutation
and do it right to left. So we put the 6 here. And then we insert the 4.

So the 4 has to
go left to the 6. And then the 8 has
to go to the right. And the 2 has to go to the left.

The 3 is less than 6,
which is less than 4. 5 is less than 6, bigger than 4.

1 sticks all the way here,
and 7 is going to fit here. So now we got this thing.

And I'm hoping I did it
right because it's supposed to give us a twin tree.
Forget this. And 7 is the root here. 7 has 1 and 8.
1 has 5 to the right.
5 has 3 and 6. 3 has 2 and 4.
And 6 is the root of this guy. And it's got 4 and 8.
It's looking good so far. 4 has 2 and 3, and 2 has 1.
2 has 3, sorry. 4 has 2 and 5.
And of course, these are-- so now it worked. So we get lots and lots.

Any permutation is going
to give you a twin tree. But there's going to be--

a lot of times, two
different permutations is going to give you
the same twin tree.

And we'll have to-- we'll
have to worry about that. But why does it always work? Well, the reason is
that L of k is empty, if

and only if k minus 1 was
inserted into this thing

before k. And R of k, you
see why this is--

I mean, let's take
4, for example.

If 3 came before 4,
then I couldn't possibly have a left child in 4 because
4 would have to be-- somehow
there's nothing between 3 and 4. So it would have to go.

And this is the same with k
plus 1, inserted before k.

So if we reverse the
permutation, k minus 1 is going to go on
the other side.

And so it can't--
they can't both be L. And they can't both be
R. And there's no room--

they have to fill up
also because there's just enough-- there's
not enough total room.

And by the way, this is also, if
I plug in k plus 1 for k here, this is also the same as saying
Rk minus 1 is unequal to null.

And this one is saying L of
k plus 1 is unequal null.

So if you look at
any of these diagrams and you look at the things
that are diagonally opposite,

there's always going to be-- this is green-red, red-green,
green-red, red-green, green-red,

red-green. This was too-- this
was too uniform. But that always happens that
you have one of them is green

and one of them is red
if I look at that, so. Now, this is something--

this tree insertion algorithm
has been something that I was playing with through
from the middle '60s.

And I always-- and I've used it
in a zillion computer program. But I never-- it took
50 years before I

understood that it also gave
me twin trees at the same time.

Now, my plan is to-- I'm talking about three
things to introduce back to permutations and floorplan.

And so I'm going to tell
you about each of the three at first. And they're going to--

and in fact, they arose
completely different-- by completely different
groups of people.

They didn't know
what they were-- they didn't know about
each other at first.

And then I'm going
to explain why there's amazing connections
between all of these three

things. So next, then, is
Baxter permutation.
And this is Glenn Baxter, 1964.

And he was studying
continuous functions-- fixed points of
continuous functions.

But during the
course of his study, he came up with
some permutations

that had peculiar properties. And Maury looked at
them, and other people started looking at
them more properly.

They were discovering. I think I first heard
about Baxter permutations when Gian-Carlo Rota gave a
lecture to the math department

in the early '70. So what are they? Well, we have a permutation
of the numbers of 1 to n--
of the numbers 1 to n.

And then I take the
inverse permutation.

So Q-- the idea is that the
inverse permutation tells you,

like Qk equals L, if
and only if Pl equals k.

It tells me where does k
appear in the permutation.

And so inside a
computer, if we want to--

somebody tells us
what P is, we quickly

compute it by saying Q of
P of l equals l for all l.

So you're given P, and
then you immediately can calculate Q inside.

So let's do it for
this random permutation that we came up
with a minute ago. So that was 7, 1,
5, 3, 2, 8, 4, 6.

And that's P. And so Q is,
well, one appeared in--
position 2.

Let's do the 7. So 7, I get a 1. 1 gets a 2, 5 gets a 3, 3 gets
a 4, 2 gets a 5, 8 gets a 6,
4 gets a 7, and 8 gets a-- no, what did I do wrong?
6 gets an 8.  That's true, 6 get--
6 gets an 8, and 6 are switched. That's fine.

I told you what
permutations are, but I haven't told you what
Baxter permutations are. So there are--

Baxter permutation has no bad
cases, no bad configurations,

where the first kind of a
bad configuration is a--

formerly, I says
Qk is less than l. Pl is less-- is greater than k.

Pl Plus 1, this
looks very scary, but I'm going to explain why
it's actually not scary at all.

But you look it up in
Wikipedia, and it'll tell you this definition. And then there's a second
case, which is bad,

and that is Qk plus 1 less than
l, Pl less than k, Pl plus 1

is greater than k, and
Qk is greater than l.

You got a question? Yeah. I'm sorry to interrupt you, but
how did you generate Q, again?

How do I generate Q? Yeah. l equals 1 up to n, so I looked
at P1, and it's equal to 7.
So I said Q7 equal to 1. Got it. All right? Yeah, thanks for asking.
Yes, please interrupt if I--

so I said P-- I said Q1 equal to 2, Q5
equal to 3, Q6 will be--

now, but Qk less
than l says that--

and Qk plus 1 is greater than
l, so here's, let's say, Pl--
and Pl plus 1 are sitting here. Then Qk is-- k is some--

k is somewhere
off on the left. k plus 1 is somewhere
off on the right,

if I'm looking at
positions, l and l plus 1 of this permutation.

But here, k plus-- Qk plus 1 is less than l. That means k plus 1
is appearing here,

and k is appearing on this side. But now, Pl is some number
that's bigger than k.

And Pl plus 1 is some
number less than k. And so-- and this would
be-- this is less than k.

So if we consider a
particular number k, this has to-- this has
to work for any k and l.

I don't want any-- I don't want to have
any badness here.

It says that we
can take-- we can-- for a fixed number
k, let's say, k

equals 4, the numbers
that are bigger than 4, let's call it big.

And the numbers that are less
than 4, let's call small. It says, I can have a
big followed by a small.

As l varies, that means
I have a big one followed by a small between k and k
plus 1, if k appears before k.

So if 4 appears before
5, I can't have a-- I can't have a big guy
and then a small guy.
So the other case is similar.

If I have k plus 1
occurring before k, then I look at all the
numbers between the two,

and I can't have a
small followed by a big.

So the smallest possible
non-Baxter permutation

is actually one of the most
famous permutations of all
is 3, 1, 4, 2. You see, take k equal to 2.
And so 1 is small and 4 is big. So I have--

I have a small
followed by a big here. Are you with me? Now, why is this such
a famous permutation?

Well, I call it the pi
mutation because everybody
knows that pi is 3.142.

But for years, I've been
working with permutations.

And I've done countless
problems where I have a conjecture about
the way permutations work.

And if the conjecture is
false, it almost always fails at the pi mutation.

So there's something
about this that makes it-- that makes it important.

So the other thing
is the inverse of the pi mutation,
which is also

the left to right reversal
of it, that fails-- that fails the first case.

Here, 2 occurs before 3. And we have a big number
followed by a little number.

So if n equals 4,
these are the only two non-Baxter permutations.
And there's 24-- 4 factorial is 24. So there's 24-- so n equals 4.

Then we have 22
Baxter permutations.
And 3, 2 and 1, it-- they're all fine. And we get 5.

That's 92 out of 120. And 6 was 422, 7 was
2,074, and 8 is 10,754.

Now, 8 factorial
is about 40,000.

So we got a chance of
something like one in four that this random mutation that
you guys came up with is Baxter

How are we going to check to
see whether 7, 1 5, 3, 2, 8, 4, 6 is Baxter?

is it bad or not? Well, we just have to
check k and k plus 1 and see what's big
and small between.

So 1 and 2 is never a problem
because everything is-- there's no small
numbers between 1 and--

nothing's less than 1. So 1 and 2, no problem. But 2 and 3, there's
nothing between them.

Between 3 and 4,
though, we've got-- 2 is small and 8 is big.
And that's bad. It looks like 3, 1, 4, 2.

No, it's not. No, no, this is fine. This is fine. This is 3 followed
by 4, so no problem.
4 and 5, now we've got to-- now we've got to have--

2 and 3 are small, and 8 is big. So that's no good. So here's a counter-example
where k is four, k plus 1.

And we have a small
followed by large. That's the-- well, it's
not a Baxter permutation.
But we could go on 5 to 6.

It seems the small
guys are like 2 and-- 2, 3, 4. And the big is 8.

So there's a mixture
of small and large. So it's failing
on that one, too. So this is OK.

But anyway, a lot of
permutations, Baxter, as you

can see from these
counts, and it's not

too hard to check a given
one by just by going-- hopping from 1 to
2 to 3 to 4 to 5.

Each time you hop, you look at
the things between that you-- and you see if the
bad and little guys

are in the right order or not. Now, one thing we can see
in order to get an idea

is if I have a Baxter
permutation, I can take it-- I can flip it left to right.

And I get another
Baxter permutation. Well, the reason is sort of
that the first rule slips

into the second rule. Another thing is I can take--
if I have a Baxter permutation

and I take its inverse, again,
I get a Baxter permutation because we sort of switched
the Q's and P's around.

But you can also put
one next to each other. So suppose I have a Baxter
permutation of 1 to m here.

This is some Baxter permutation. And here I have another
Baxter permutation of m plus 1

through n. So these are numbers 1
to m are in some order.

But they qualify as Baxter. And here, it's the same
thing, except I added m to each of them.

So I got to-- I took another
Baxter permutation, but promoted every number,
make it bigger than m.

This is going to be--
this is going to be fine. Why? Because I go from 1 to
2 to 3 to 4, and so on,

and I don't get
any bad cases here. And then I jump
from m to m plus 1.

Well, all of the small
guys are going to be-- are all going to come first,
and the big guys later

between m and m plus 1. And then once I'm
up into this half, and again I jump m
plus 2 and so on,

and I never get any
bad situation again. So this is a Baxter. Did you get it?

A Baxter permutation
by sort of juxtaposing. I could also do it this way.

I could put the-- I could put the n plus
1 to n at the left and 1 to m at the right.

And again, it'll jump around,
but it'll work out fine.

So anyway, you can
see why there's a variety of Baxter
permutations. And now it's time for topic 3.
Topic 3 is floorplans.

And this is something that is
a decomposition of rectangle

into rectangle
into subrectangles.

And now-- I guess I might
as well give you an example.

So right off, I'll take
this rectangle here,
and I'm going to subdivide it.

Give me a minute to write some
coordinates here, V3, V4, V5,
and h0, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6.

So this is a 5 by 6 grid. And I'm going to divide
it into subrectangles.

And I'm going-- this
one goes down to h3.

And then I'm going
to put one here. And I'm going to
carry this over on V3.

I want to-- I could have prepared
a slide here,

but I didn't want to
go too fast, you see. So G and that--

so here-- so I'm going
to call this A, B, C.

The subrectangles
are called rooms. So I got 10 rooms here, C, D,
E, F, G, H, I, J. And the line
segments that are the-- so rectangle is a room.

And the segments
is called a bound.

So every room has
four segments that

bound on the top left,
right, and bottom. And so I've got--

in this case, I've
got a segment h0, I've got h1, h2,
h3, h4, h5, and h6.

And I've got-- and I've
got vertical segments also. I used a V, so I
remember it's vertical.

This is actually supposed
to be one straight line. And so, this, as
you can imagine,

concept is very important
in layout of a VLSI,

making silicon chips
because the rooms correspond

to modules or
gates of a circuit, and the bounds
correspond to channel.
So, where-- electrical circuit.

So now, the--  I should mention that in this
decomposition of rectangles,

we always have the
tatami condition, which means that no four rectangles
have the same corner point.

In Japan, they have this
wonderful age-old custom

of covering their
floor with tatami mats. And the rule is, you don't
have ever a situation where

something like this would be
bad because there are four--

this corner, we have four tatami
mat touching the same point.

So anyway, that's the kind
of a-- you generate thing.
And now the interesting thing--

the important thing
is when we discuss

what does it mean for
two different floorplans to be the same because there's
an equivalence-- there's

an equivalence between floor
plans, which means that it's going to give you
the same circuit, for example, if you
make a chip out of it.

So I can actually draw
that exact same floorplan.

But it'll look
different if I put the--

if I put the bounds
in different order. So here, I'm going to do
V0, V2, V1, V3, V4, V5.

And in the horizontal,
I'm going to go h0, h1, h3, h5, h2, h4, h6.

And I'm going to-- I'm going to draw the
exact same floorplan. So A went from h0
to h3 and V0 to V1.

So it's going to be
h0 to h3 and V0 to V1. So this is going to be A now.
B goes across on h1.
C is between V1 and V3--

V1 and V3, which is
just this little-- this little thing here.
So C is between h1 and h3. G goes h1 to h2.

So G is now going
here, and so on.

So I'm going to get
D between h3 and h5.
And then E is down here. F is this big guy.

H, I, and J. And I claim
that this is the same diagram

because each rectangle
has the same boundaries.

So it needs some
notation for this.

So, say, for example,
V0 right arrow A, V1

this means that V0
is at the left of A, and V1 is at the right of A.
And h0 is above A--
at above h3. And so I've got 10 rooms here.

And so I'm going to have-- there's 40 different relations
between these things.

But the idea is
that two floorplans are equivalent if they
have the same relations.

In other words, if there's
a one-to-one correspondence between the rooms, so
like the two-- room

A here corresponds to room
A here and the bounds. So bound h0 corresponds
to h0, h1 corresponds--

h3, h2, got here. And so all of these relations
are preserved between these two

things.  I put the labels on
just so you can see

what matches between the two. But I could have made the
labels blank, and I would say,

this floor plan is
equivalent to this floor plan because there's a one-to-one
correspondence between the rooms

and the bounds. All right, now, you
got questions on this?

So, if you're
representing the two--

Please speak very loudly. I forgot to wear my hearing aid. So if you're representing
the two floorplans as graphs,

it will be of the exact same? If I represent as
graphs, then what? So the rooms are going to--
and then if you share a bound,

it's an edge. So would the graphs
be isomorphic?

The graphs are-- well,
if you label the--

but you have to consider
the different kinds of arcs, the horizontal
arc and a vertical arc.
So the graphs are isomorphic.

But you have to
distinguish a horizontal. If I didn't distinguish
horizontal from vertical,

then it would be a
different concept. Now, but the-- but you
talked about representation.

And of course, one of
the things we want to do is represent this in a
computer in some way. And we'd like to have a
representation that equivalent

floorplans have the-- look
the same inside the computer or easy to tell that
this one equals that one.

So, now I want to
explain to you how

we can get a canonical form
that I can take any floorplan,

and I can draw--  I can draw it in a certain
way so that both of these

would turn out to be-- to have the same result.
So there are 10 rooms.

And for this canonical
form, I'm going to use-- I'm going to use
this kind of paper.

And I'm going to give myself
10 by 10 area to work with.

So one, two, three, four, five,
six, seven, eight, nine, 10.

So that you can see what
I'm doing, I guess I can--

two, three, four, five,
six, seven, eight, nine, 10.

So I'm going to-- I'm going to-- redraw this
floorplan in a canonical way

that both of these are
going to end up the same.

So I might as well just
use this one to start with.

And now you notice that
inside of floorplan,

I said we got the
tatami condition. So there's only four kinds of
junctions that we can have.

A junction can look like
this, it can look like this, or it can look like this,
or it can look like that. But we-- at the corners,
we only have two.

But otherwise, these
are all junctions. And so I start at the
upper left-hand corner.
And I put the-- put it here. And then I look at the lower--
at the lower part of that room.

And I see that it ends-- it ends with a upside down T
junction for A. So it's up--

in the lower
right-hand corner, it's an A, which means that the
boundary here, the right bound

is this vertical bound V1. And then there's going to be
a neighbor on the other side.

Now, the fundamental idea
is called flattening.

And so I'm going to take-- I'm going to take
A here, and I'm going to flatten it
by moving this bound

all the way to the left and
smashing A so its width has gone down to zero.

And then A-- so this B and this
line is going to extend over.
It's going to--

I'm not going to
